text: Hi, class.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So today I'll be talking about climate change and species responses to climate change.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And what I'll be showing you today is what we can learn from the geological record in terms of understanding past climatic events and how species responded to those climatic events.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: All right, so the first context here, and this could be a lecture into itself, which I'm not going to go into right now, is the point that the world is warming and that humans are responsible for it.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: There's been a lot of debate about this in the public media, but again, I want to hit the point that scientists are unified on this one.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: The evidence is overwhelming at this point that the world is warming and humans are responsible.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So you look at the plot there, you can see the black line, which shows historical observations of global mean temperatures over the last century.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: You can see there's been about a seven tenths of a degree warming.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Now, if you look to the future, which is those various blue lines, you can see that the various models project an acceleration of these warming trends over this century.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And depending on the scenario you look at from blue to red there, you can have anywhere from about a two degree warming to about a four degree warming.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Now, you can ignore that yellow red line at the bottom there.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: That's more of a what if scenario.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: If we weren't to do, if we were to shut down CO2 and other greenhouse gases emissions immediately, what would happen to the climate system, which is clearly not going to happen anytime soon.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So the point being that we are facing of two to four degree warming over the century, and the question then being what will happen?
Speaker: SPK_1

text: How will the physical systems respond in terms of hurricane frequency, flood frequency, how will species and natural ecosystems respond?
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And how will our own societies respond to these drastic changes in climate?
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So one place we can learn to look to this sort of answer to these sort of questions is looking to the last 20,000 years or so.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: If you look at that map up atop what you can see there is that 20,000 years ago, we had a large ice sheet on top of the northern hemisphere, covering much of North America and the rest of the northern hemisphere, contrasted with the map at right there, which shows that ice, which is more the present day state ice, being confined mainly to Greenland.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So we've gone from a glacial state to an interglacial state in a span of about 20,000 years.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: That red curve at bottom shows that we've gone from about a ten degree change in Greenland.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: This is a temperature record from Greenland.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: We go from about, at left, 20,000 years ago to right present day.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: You can see several abrupt warming and coolings along the way, these abrupt transitional events.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And so we have a very good geological record and understanding of the climatic changes of the past.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And so now we can look at the ecological responses to those climatic changes.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So what are some of the things we can pull out from these sorts of data?
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Well, we look at fossil pollen and other plant records.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: One of the things we can see is that species ranges are highly dynamic.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: As climate changes, species migrate.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: You can see this here, where you can see at the top there, the left hand panel is for 21,000 years ago, going to the right at present.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And you can see how ice melts away as you go from map to map there.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: But then look at the green, which is the distribution of spruce based upon fossil pollen and other fossil plant records.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: You can see how the distribution of spruce has changed from being mainly in the eastern US to being across Canada over the span of these 20,000 years.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So ranges are highly dynamic.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Now, of course, trees aren't picking up and moving.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: They're not walking from point a to point b, but instead they're dispersing seeds.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Some of these seeds established in new areas, they can colonize and establish new populations.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And in other areas where spruce used to grow, those areas become unfavorable and those populations die off.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So that's how we have these range shifts of these species.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Now, a piece of good news in the geological record is that we don't have very many observed extinctions of Plants over the last 20,000 years.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: Plant species, I should say.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: One example of where we do is shown here in this diagram.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: This is some cross sections of some spruce needles.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: There's the first four.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: A through d are from still living species of spruce.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: E through g are from extinct species of spruce.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: And so there's some clear evidence from fossil records in the late glacial that there's a set of spruce species that grew in the past that are not found today.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: So species do go extinct, but this is more the exception than the rule.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: However, if you combine climate change with other drivers, other stressors to these natural systems, that's when you can have widespread and potentially devastating ways of extinctions.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: The most famous ones occur again, Pleistocene here, with the extinction of mammoths and other large mammals from North America.
Speaker: SPK_1

text: These were caused by the.
Speaker: SPK_1
